meta.title: Environmental Data Hub & Health Linkage — Wisdom → FAIR/Openness → Integration → Governance → Services → Improvement → Cases
meta.subtitle: A lattice for the NERC Digital Solutions Hub story: connect environmental archives to socio-economic & health questions via governance, UPRN services, TRE workflows, and metadata-grounded AI navigation.
meta.domainName: environmental data hubs and environment–health linkage
meta.searchPlaceholder: FAIR, NERC, DEFRA, Met Office, Environment Agency, raster vs vector, CRS, OGC, ISO 19115, DCAT, UPRN, TRE, GDPR, DPIA, RAG, ESRI Enterprise, Azure, FinOps, hotspot analysis, deprivation (IMD), asthma, cancer, UK Biobank…
meta.userContextPlaceholder: e.g., city/region; target outcome (asthma/cancer/heat); available health data (aggregate vs individual); your TRE constraints; budget limits; partner datasets…
meta.promptTemplate:
You're advising a cross-sector team building or using a data hub to study environment–health questions.

Goal: produce a concrete narrative case study and an action plan grounded in the selected nodes.

USER CONTEXT (optional):
{{USER_CONTEXT}}

SELECTED NODES:
{{SELECTED_TITLES}}

DETAILS (with relationships):
{{SELECTED_DETAILS}}

TRACE PATHS:
{{TRACE_SUMMARY}}

INSTRUCTIONS:
1) Start by asking the user to choose (or invent) a SPECIFIC CASE that matches their context. Offer 6–10 case prompts derived from the selected 'case' nodes (or propose plausible variants if none selected).
   - Include choices like: city/region, time window, environmental indicators, health outcome, and whether linkage is aggregate or individual-level in a TRE.
2) Write a realistic narrative of the chosen case, including stakeholders (e.g., local authority, NHS/TRE, DEFRA/Met Office, academics, community).
3) Explain the technical pipeline (formats/resolutions, ETL, overlays, UPRN extraction) and the governance pipeline (FAIR/licensing, GDPR/DPIA, TRE boundaries).
4) Identify 5–8 risks/pathologies (resolution misuse, cost runaway, AI hallucination, skills gaps) and mitigation controls (standards, observability, guardrails).
5) Deliver an implementation playbook:
   - Data acquisition & harmonisation steps
   - Service/API design (including UPRN extraction)
   - TRE workflow for sensitive analysis
   - Metadata + RAG approach for user navigation
   - Measurement plan (usage, cost, data quality, user satisfaction)
6) End with 2 safe-to-fail experiments and clear success/backfire signals.

levels.title: Wisdom & stewardship
levels.hint: Judgement-in-context: public value, trust, humility, and long-term stewardship of data ecosystems.

levels.title: Super-concepts
levels.hint: Shaping ideas: openness, privacy, legitimacy, uncertainty, incentives, user needs, and environmental justice.

levels.title: Systems & data-integration concepts
levels.hint: How data platforms behave: heterogeneity, pipelines, provenance, interoperability, feedback loops, and socio-technical coupling.

levels.title: Governance & programme architecture
levels.hint: Policies, standards, contracts, access models, and cross-organisation collaboration that make linkage possible.

levels.title: Operational delivery mechanisms
levels.hint: Data engineering + geospatial methods + services: ingest, harmonise, overlay, extract-by-UPRN, deploy, monitor.

levels.title: Quality, performance & improvement
levels.hint: Assurance, cost control, usability, auditability, evaluation, and learning cycles (including AI/RAG guardrails).

levels.title: Cases, challenges & pathologies
levels.hint: Concrete scenarios, failure modes and exemplar use cases (pollution, deprivation, cancer, asthma, cloud budgeting, TRE enablement).

nodes.label: Public value over novelty
nodes.summary: Optimise for societal use and decision impact, not just academic publication.
nodes.bodyHtml: Design choices should prioritise real-world decisions (planning, health, policy) and equitable benefit—especially for non-academic users.

nodes.label: Trust through transparency
nodes.summary: Make provenance, limitations, and governance legible so users can rely on outputs.
nodes.bodyHtml: Trust is earned by clearly communicating what data can/can’t say, how it was produced, and how access is governed—particularly at the environment–health boundary.

nodes.label: User-led design (start with needs)
nodes.summary: Workshops and co-design prevent ‘expert-built, unused’ platforms.
nodes.bodyHtml: Begin by eliciting user challenges (access, interpretation, formats). Build iteratively from those constraints rather than assuming what users need.

nodes.label: Humility about uncertainty
nodes.summary: Expose model limits; avoid false precision; invite critique and revision.
nodes.bodyHtml: Environmental models, gridded rasters, and linkage assumptions carry uncertainty. Honest framing prevents brittle decisions and reputational harm.

nodes.label: Respect boundaries (privacy & purpose)
nodes.summary: Move open data outward; keep sensitive health data inside TREs.
nodes.bodyHtml: Architecture should embody data minimisation: export environmental indicators to trusted environments rather than importing identifiable health records into open platforms.

nodes.label: Learning loops over one-off delivery
nodes.summary: Treat the platform as a living system; keep adapting via feedback.
nodes.bodyHtml: Workshops, user testing, usage monitoring, and post-incident learning keep the system aligned with evolving needs and constraints.

nodes.label: FAIR data principles
nodes.summary: Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable—especially for non-academic audiences.
nodes.bodyHtml: FAIR is a design target: identifiers, rich metadata, open interfaces, and clear licensing enable reuse beyond academia.

nodes.label: Open data (as default for environment)
nodes.summary: Most environmental datasets are open; openness enables wide uptake.
nodes.bodyHtml: Open environmental data reduces friction for cross-sector use, but linkage with population data introduces governance complexity.

nodes.label: Environmental determinants of health
nodes.summary: Air pollution, temperature, noise and other exposures shape health outcomes.
nodes.bodyHtml: Linking environmental indicators to health outcomes enables epidemiology, prevention, and urban policy evaluation.

nodes.label: Environmental justice & deprivation
nodes.summary: Unequal exposure burdens intersect with deprivation and vulnerability.
nodes.bodyHtml: Analyses often ask: are deprived neighbourhoods disproportionately exposed to pollution or heat risk?

nodes.label: Privacy, trust & social licence
nodes.summary: Legitimacy for linkage depends on perceived fairness and safeguards.
nodes.bodyHtml: Even when legally permissible, linkage can fail socially if people believe data use is opaque, extractive or unsafe.

nodes.label: Incentives & fixed-budget constraints
nodes.summary: Cloud scaling is attractive, but variable costs can threaten sustainability.
nodes.bodyHtml: Universities and public projects often operate on fixed grants; cost uncertainty becomes a governance and design constraint.

nodes.label: Information → knowledge → wisdom ladder
nodes.summary: More data ≠ better decisions; interpretation and context matter.
nodes.bodyHtml: Data hubs must provide context, metadata, and tools so users can move from raw layers to actionable understanding.

nodes.label: Non-academic user diversity
nodes.summary: Public, private and third sector users have different questions and constraints.
nodes.bodyHtml: Data products should support multiple skill levels: map-based exploration, APIs, and export workflows into specialist environments.

nodes.label: Multi-source data linkage
nodes.summary: Value arises when environmental data connects with socio-economic and health datasets.
nodes.bodyHtml: Linkage enables richer causal questions than single-source analysis, but increases heterogeneity and governance complexity.

nodes.label: Spatial heterogeneity (raster vs vector)
nodes.summary: Grid rasters, points (sensors/UPRNs), and polygons (neighbourhoods) must interoperate.
nodes.bodyHtml: Different spatial representations require overlay/sampling methods and careful interpretation of resolution effects.

nodes.label: Temporal heterogeneity
nodes.summary: Sensors stream frequently; models update on different cycles; health data has its own cadence.
nodes.bodyHtml: Analysis often requires alignment: aggregation, interpolation, windowing, and attention to lag/latency.

nodes.label: Resolution mismatch & ecological fallacy
nodes.summary: Coarse grids can hide local variation; small-area inference can mislead.
nodes.bodyHtml: Using 5km gridded pollution for neighbourhood health inference can introduce misclassification and biased associations.

nodes.label: Provenance & metadata as first-class
nodes.summary: Trust depends on knowing lineage, methods, and coverage.
nodes.bodyHtml: Metadata enables fitness-for-purpose checks: spatial extent, time span, uncertainty, and collection method.

nodes.label: Interoperability standards (OGC/DCAT/ISO 19115)
nodes.summary: Common schemas and APIs reduce friction across organisations.
nodes.bodyHtml: Standards support discoverability and automated ingestion, but need consistent implementation and governance.

nodes.label: Socio-technical platform thinking
nodes.summary: The platform includes people, processes, incentives and tools—not just software.
nodes.bodyHtml: Workshops, training, support, and organisational agreements are as important as pipelines and cloud architecture.

nodes.label: Data engineering (assimilation & harmonisation)
nodes.summary: ETL/ELT, format conversion, QA, and indexing make data usable.
nodes.bodyHtml: Much effort sits ‘under the covers’: converting formats, aligning CRS, building indices, and managing storage/performance.

nodes.label: Geospatial & statistical methods
nodes.summary: Overlay, hotspot analysis, exposure assignment and spatio-temporal modelling.
nodes.bodyHtml: Methods choice is constrained by data type, resolution, and availability inside user environments (e.g., TREs).

nodes.label: User feedback loops
nodes.summary: Workshops → prototypes → testing → revision drives adoption and fit.
nodes.bodyHtml: User-led iteration reduces misfit, improves interface clarity, and surfaces governance concerns early.

nodes.label: RAG grounding to reduce hallucination
nodes.summary: LLM answers are constrained by retrieved metadata rather than free generation.
nodes.bodyHtml: Retrieval-augmented generation uses a metadata index so summaries and answers are grounded in documented sources.

nodes.label: Federated data centres (NERC)
nodes.summary: Environmental data distributed across centres by type; federation requires coherent access patterns.
nodes.bodyHtml: Large-scale archives (tens of PB) span multiple centres. Federation needs consistent cataloguing and access interfaces.

nodes.label: Licensing & access model
nodes.summary: Open licensing for environment; constrained access pathways for sensitive linkage.
nodes.bodyHtml: Governance defines what is openly accessible, what requires safeguards, and how users authenticate/authorise.

nodes.label: GDPR / DPIA / purpose limitation
nodes.summary: Controls for personal data processing, risk assessment, and lawful basis.
nodes.bodyHtml: When linkage approaches personal data, DPIAs and purpose limitation help maintain compliance and trust.

nodes.label: Trusted Research Environments (TREs)
nodes.summary: Secure enclaves for sensitive individual-level health data with controlled tools and outputs.
nodes.bodyHtml: Rather than exporting health data, users bring derived environmental indicators into the TRE for analysis under governance.

nodes.label: UPRN as a join key (property-level linkage)
nodes.summary: More precise than postcode; supports apartment-level differentiation and height-aware indicators.
nodes.bodyHtml: UPRNs anchor environmental indicator assignment to specific properties and enable joining to health records already keyed by UPRN.

nodes.label: Cross-organisation collaboration
nodes.summary: Met Office, DEFRA, Environment Agency, NHS, local authorities, academia—shared value requires coordination.
nodes.bodyHtml: Shared standards, aligned expectations, and joint workshops enable data reuse across sectors.

nodes.label: Platform roadmap & release governance
nodes.summary: Pilot → user testing → public release; manage expectations and change control.
nodes.bodyHtml: Staged rollout reduces risk, supports training, and enables iterative improvement before wider launch.

nodes.label: Workforce scarcity & skill-mix risk
nodes.summary: Hard to hire people who can span cloud, GIS, engineering and product delivery.
nodes.bodyHtml: Pivots (on-prem → cloud) expose skills gaps; resilience requires redundancy, training and role clarity.

nodes.label: GIS platform stack (ESRI Enterprise)
nodes.summary: Online-deployable GIS CMS for spatial data plus custom tools.
nodes.bodyHtml: Enterprise GIS provides cataloguing, mapping, and service endpoints; custom tools sit on top for ingestion and extraction.

nodes.label: Cloud deployment (Azure) with scaling
nodes.summary: Elastic compute and storage; scale with demand.
nodes.bodyHtml: Cloud enables elasticity and rapid provisioning, but requires cost controls, monitoring, and governance.

nodes.label: Cost controls (runtime windows, monitoring)
nodes.summary: Turn off services out of hours; monitor granular spend and usage.
nodes.bodyHtml: Operational levers include scheduled uptime, quotas, caching, and usage analytics to manage variable cloud bills.

nodes.label: ETL harmonisation pipeline
nodes.summary: Format conversion, CRS alignment, metadata capture, and indexing into a common system.
nodes.bodyHtml: Includes raster tiling, vector normalisation, schema mapping, and provenance logging.

nodes.label: Spatial overlay & sampling
nodes.summary: Point-in-polygon, raster sampling at points, neighbourhood aggregation, hotspot methods.
nodes.bodyHtml: Core operation for exposure assignment: attach environmental indicators to UPRNs or areas.

nodes.label: UPRN extraction service
nodes.summary: Select region + indicators → export UPRN-level environmental attributes.
nodes.bodyHtml: Users define an area, choose indicators (e.g., black carbon, noise, heat), and download a UPRN-keyed table for use inside a TRE.

nodes.label: Pilot TRE with geospatial tooling (AWS)
nodes.summary: Deploy GIS inside a TRE to enable spatial work without heavy coding.
nodes.bodyHtml: A pilot TRE includes geospatial software so researchers can bring in spatial layers and conduct GIS analyses securely.

nodes.label: Metadata indexing (40 PB → searchable catalogue)
nodes.summary: Extract and store metadata centrally for discovery and AI-assisted summarisation.
nodes.bodyHtml: Centralised metadata enables search, filtering, and AI summaries without moving the underlying petabyte-scale datasets.

nodes.label: Ask-AI interface (RAG summaries)
nodes.summary: 250-word grounded dataset summaries; Q&A over metadata.
nodes.bodyHtml: Users ask about coverage, resolution, timespan, provenance; answers are grounded in the metadata store to reduce hallucination.

nodes.label: Training & enablement workshops
nodes.summary: Hands-on sessions to teach extraction workflows and build confidence.
nodes.bodyHtml: Workshops support new services (e.g., UPRN extraction), gather feedback, and accelerate uptake across sectors.

nodes.label: Data quality & uncertainty communication
nodes.summary: Expose uncertainty, coverage and caveats; keep links to primary documentation.
nodes.bodyHtml: Quality is not only numeric accuracy: it’s clarity about limitations, provenance, and appropriate uses.

nodes.label: Platform observability
nodes.summary: Usage analytics, performance monitoring, and cost telemetry to support governance decisions.
nodes.bodyHtml: Observability enables tuning (caching, scaling), cost control, and prioritisation of improvements based on real use.

nodes.label: Usability for mixed-skill users
nodes.summary: Map-first exploration plus export/API pathways; reduce expert-only barriers.
nodes.bodyHtml: Non-academic users need clear workflows, help tools, and sensible defaults while still supporting advanced users.

nodes.label: AI guardrails & evaluation
nodes.summary: Grounding, citation to metadata, prompt constraints, and continuous evaluation for failures.
nodes.bodyHtml: Measure hallucination rate, refusal correctness, and user trust. Keep a human-readable provenance trail for AI outputs.

nodes.label: Interoperability compliance testing
nodes.summary: Validate services against standards; prevent drift in schemas/APIs.
nodes.bodyHtml: Regular checks ensure that ingest/export and APIs remain compatible with partner systems and user pipelines.

nodes.label: Continuous improvement (PDCA / agile delivery)
nodes.summary: Iterate: plan → build → test → learn → release.
nodes.bodyHtml: Combines user-led discovery with disciplined release management and post-release learning.

nodes.label: Case: Manchester local pollution estimation
nodes.summary: Combine gridded model rasters with DEFRA point monitors for finer local insight.
nodes.bodyHtml: Use raster model outputs (e.g., 5km) alongside point-source monitors to improve local relevance for urban analyses.

nodes.label: Case: Deprivation–pollution spatial relationship (IMD 2019→2025)
nodes.summary: Overlay IMD neighbourhood polygons with air pollution layers to explore inequities over time.
nodes.bodyHtml: Analyse whether pollution burdens track deprivation, and whether patterns change after policy interventions.

nodes.label: Case: Christie cancer records + UPRN environmental linkage
nodes.summary: Export UPRN-keyed indicators to a TRE and join to cancer records for exposure–risk studies.
nodes.bodyHtml: Researchers join environmental indicator tables to individual cancer records within a secure environment to study spatial/temporal associations.

nodes.label: Case: Asthma triggers via prescribing + pollution
nodes.summary: Join prescribing/health indicators with rich environmental exposures to study triggers and hotspots.
nodes.bodyHtml: Enable spatio-temporal analyses of asthma-related prescribing against pollution/noise/temperature indicators.

nodes.label: Case: UK Biobank UPRN attachment pipeline
nodes.summary: Attach UPRNs to cohort participants so environmental indicators can be added consistently.
nodes.bodyHtml: UPRN attachment supports systematic enrichment of cohort data with environmental exposures for long-term studies.

nodes.label: Challenge: On-prem → cloud pivot mid-project
nodes.summary: Architecture change creates delays, skills gaps, and unexpected costs.
nodes.bodyHtml: Switching deployment model requires retooling, new roles, and revised governance around cost and security.

nodes.label: Pathology: Runaway cloud costs
nodes.summary: Popularity increases spend; fixed grants get squeezed; services risk being throttled or shut down.
nodes.bodyHtml: Without quotas, scheduling, caching and governance, success can become financially unsustainable.

nodes.label: Pathology: AI hallucination erodes trust
nodes.summary: Ungrounded summaries can mislead; users may over-trust fluent answers.
nodes.bodyHtml: RAG grounding + evaluation + clear caveats are needed so AI helps navigation without inventing facts.

nodes.label: Pathology: Misuse of coarse rasters for fine decisions
nodes.summary: Treating 5km grid values as street-level truth can drive wrong interventions.
nodes.bodyHtml: Provide tooling and guidance for downscaling/validation, and communicate fitness-for-purpose prominently.
